Hate to break it to you, but fitting an equation to measurements is done all the time and across many, many fields of science and engineering. What I accomplished was a simplification of the physics (but not overly simplified) and then determined the two parameters via parameter estimation methods, AKA mulitple regression, and then some statistical analysis for quality.

Sorry to break it to you again, but I doubt that multi-parameter estimation is thought to freshmen, and surely R^2 abd autoregression is not. Typically these are never thought at all but rather informally picked up as needed during graduate study. It has become clear to me that a more formal approach to the statistical analysis of data, especially time series, is rather widely needed; otherwise the research program needs engage a professional statistician as seems to becoming more common in at least climatology.

As for noise, the estimated parameters give R^2=0.991 which is d****d good; there is essentially nothing left to explain as the autocorrelations show mere white noise. If one uses a more complex model as in G. Hegerl, T. Crowley, M. Allen, W. Hyde, H. Pollack, J. Smerdon and E. Zorita. Detection of human influence on a new, validated 1500-year temperature reconstruction. J. of Climate 20, 650 (2007), then one finds a somewhat different description of temperatures over a longer time interval and a different attribution to anthropogenic causes in the 20th century. (I intend to compare my simple model to this paper,
easily obtainable from at least the publications websites of the first and last authors.
In particular, I believe you'll find Figures 3 and 5 (at the end of the paper) both rathr full of unexplained noise and nobody is in the slightest concerned about it.

wmar (62) --- Thanks for readin it. First, the formula
AE(d) = k(lnCO2(d-1) - lnCO2(1870s)) - GTA(1880s)
is correct for the heating due to excess CO2, to quite a decent approximation. Second, it is true that I assumed near equilibrium for the 1880s. That is only approximately correct of course as CO2 concentrations were already increasing from industrialization and deforestation, but off-set in effect by the eruption of Krakatoa. Given that I obtain R^2=0.991 there seemed (and still seems) little point in making further adjustments for the decade of the 1880s.

But most important, any trend in climate has to have a cause. The climate system does not have an elastic component to rebound after an applied force is removed. The earlier trend, observable in Figure 3 of the Hegerl et al. paper I cited in my just earlier comment, is simply responding to the forcings given in Figure 6. In particular, notice that the lack of dimming due to the lack or volcano eruptions combines with "GHGs+Aerosols" to provide warming once the effect of Krakatoa is over.

Please do read and understand the main thrust of that paper.

73. Harry Eagar You are right about the chancy nature of farming. Primitive farming is even more seriously affected, since it has fewer ways to adapt.

For a farmer was the time of planting, a game of chance, is helped by astronomy. Plant too early - it's likely to freeze. Plant too late, it doesn't have time to ripen. You need to know what day of the year you are in.

An understanding of the movement of the Earth on the ecliptic was absolutely essential. Modern math and physics - Newton's calculus - came out of this farming - climate driven fundamental problem of planting time leading to planet movement.

I am a mathematical physicist, and I trace the root of my line of work precisely to this fundamental problem. I make a point about teaching Newton's proof of Kepler's empirical observations of planet movement to all my students - still beautiful after 400 years. You start from universal attraction - a 1/4 of a line - and with a cascade of clever math you end up with the exact movement of planets on ellipses - you can even "weigh" them from their period. It shows that mathematics is the language of nature.

This year I started to add the climate - farming angle to it....

'ScienceDaily (Jan. 27, 2000) — Twice an Exxon Valdez spill worth of oil seeps into the Gulf of Mexico every year, according to a new study that will be presented January 27 at the Ocean Sciences Meeting in San Antonio, Texas.'

The oil bubbles up from a cracks in ocean bottom sediments and spreads out with the wind to an to an area covering about 4 square miles.'

This is a horrible disaster, loss of life and potential environmental mess of great proportions, but just like the Valdez spill, man and nature will clean it and the area will heal. We can all agree we need more sources of clean and safe energy.

Who ever thought a 'clean' wind project could result in a vast and killing oil spill which would devastate its area just as a spill anywhere would ... the difference being, who knew a wind project featured 40,000 plus 19,500 gallons of oil within it on and over the waters just offshore over spawning grounds and shipping lanes. Prophetic article last year by Warren Cornwall, Seattle Times environment reporter, prompted by a report issued by the state's Oil Spill Advisory Council about the potential for successful response to a major oil spill in Puget Sound or coastal Washington that could easily have been describing this weeks gulf spill @
http://seattletimes.nwsource.com...
Some pithy parts:
- two decades after the Exxon Valdez dumped more than five times that much oil into Alaska's Prince William Sound, there's still concern that emergency crews would be overwhelmed by a catastrophic spill here. The sheer difficulty of getting oil out of water, coupled with unpredictable weather, fierce currents and thousands of miles of shoreline, make any attempt to tackle a big spill in Puget Sound uncertain at best. Despite spending tens of millions of dollars each year preparing for oil spills and cleaning them up — and despite having some of the nation's toughest oil-spill standards — some experts warn the state is not as ready for a big accident as we think we are. "I strongly feel we need to be better prepared," said Mike Cooper, chairman of the state's Oil Spill Advisory Council, a task force created to police oil-spill programs.
- Cooper said the state should require a big boost in spill equipment from industries — enough to suck up 70 percent of a Valdez-size spill within two days.
- "I'm here to tell you, every piece of equipment in the world, if it was brought to bear, couldn't do that," Richard Wright said of Cooper's goal. Wright is the Northwest regional vice president of Marine Spill Response, a nonprofit funded by the oil industry to handle oil spills.
- "The report would seem to indicate and support quite strongly the supposition that we are not prepared to respond to a large-scale oil spill," said Scott McCreery of BP [!!], who sits on the spill council. "And I have grave concerns that that's real misleading to the public."
- A lead spill official for the Coast Guard in Seattle, Scott Knutson, said the report showed potential weaknesses that warrant closer study. He pointed to the recommendation for better equipment to track oil spills at night or in fog. "We have some gaps there. No doubt about it," he said.
- ... the state already requires more equipment on hand than federal standards call for ...

Well, the "fatal error" as usual seems to be not looking for the fatal errors, but looking only the "fixes" that let major risk taking get through.

Our actual environmental plan, necessitated by our economic model relying on ever increasing control of the earth for producing short term wealth for investors, is to proceed with ever greater risk-taking till something happens, hoping we're not the ones that get caught. That reasoning, of course, assures we're certain to be the ones that get caught, and be totally surprised by it too.

The practical solution is looking for how natural systems demonstrate the way to cap the risks and complications of continuing growth by maturing, switching to simplifying their tasks rather than multiplying their challenges.

All undersea oil drilling should have a fail-proof valve at the entry point to the earth that is developed, installed and monitored by an independent firm that answers to the government of the country where the oil wells are located. The valves should meet an international standard and be operable remotely by the independent firm or agency. They should be paid for by the oil industry and considered a type of insurance. It is the least we can do whether we are for or against drilling for oil.
